item.title: Working with genomes in Python: sequence cuts by restriction enzymes
item.description: Assume that we are interested in two restriction enzymes with binding sites ANTAAT and GCRWTG, respectively. (N is any base, R is A or G, W is A or T) We can use re.findall() in Python to find the matching restriction enzyme binding sites in the following sequence. import re seq="" re.findall(r'A.TAAT', seq) ## ['ATTAAT', 'ACTAAT'] re.findall(r'GC[AG][AT]TG', seq) ## ['GCGTTG', 'GCAATG'] Assume the restriction enzymes cut the sequence above bluntly at the midpoint of the binding site, so ANT/ATT and GCR/WTG.

item.title: Working with genomes in Python: finding 3-mers
item.description: In bioinformatics, k-mers refer to all the possible subsequences (of length k) from a read obtained through DNA sequencing. For example, if the DNA sequencing read is “ATCATCATG”, then the 3-mers in that read include “ATC” (which occurs twice), “TCA” (which occurs twice), “CAT” (occurs twice), and “ATG” (occurs once). We can write a function in Python that takes a string of nucleotides as input and returns a dictionary with all 3-mers present in that string, and the number of times that each 3-mer occurs.

item.title: Working with genomes in Python: calculating pairwise sequence identity
item.description: In bioinformatics, we are often interested in determining whether or not two DNA or amino acid sequences are similar. One simple measure of similarity is called pairwise sequence identity. To calculate pairwise sequence identity, we take two sequences, count the number of positions in which both sequences share the same nucleotide or amino acid, and then divide by the total number of positions. For example, say we have these two DNA sequences:

item.title: How R and Python can work together
item.description: It may not come as a surprise to you that one can write Python codes in R studio. But wouldn’t it be super cool if a variable created in R code chunk could also be used in Python code chunk in R studio? Believe it or not, you could actually have R and Python “communicate” with each other with the help of the reticulate package. Now, I will show you one of the coolest tricks I have learned in my SDS 348 class at UT Austin.

item.title: SDS348 Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: 0. Introduction library(boot) melanoma <- as.data.frame(melanoma) I chose the melanoma dataset from the boot package. The melanoma dataset was generated from a melanoma cancer study and contains information regarding patients survival from malignant melanoma. There are total of 205 observations and 7 different variables. Each observation represents a patient, who had tumor removed by surgery at the Department of Plastic Surgery, University Hopspital of Odense, Denmark. The status of the patients was also followed after the surgery.

item.title: SDS348 Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis with Tidyverse Tools
item.description: 0. Introduction I have chosen the COVID-19 confirmed cases, deaths, and recovered datasets. As the novel coronavirus spreads to the U.S. and is recently considered a pandemic by WHO, it is important that we continuously monitor the nubmer of cases confirmed, the number of deaths, and the nubmer of recovered everyday. The Johns Hopkins University has been doing a great job in keeping track of the number of confirmed cases and deaths everyday and has been updating the datasets on this website: https://data.

item.title: Projects
item.description: Projects Here are some projects I have recently completed: Exploratory Data Analysis with Tidyverse Tools Modeling, Testing, and Classification

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.
